=head1 NAME
gptrans_conv
=head1 REVISION
$Id$
=head1 SYNOPSIS
B [options] [file [files [...]]]
B -S [options] [file [files [...]]]
B -u [options] [file [files [...]]]
=head1 DESCRIPTION
=head1 OPTIONS
=over 4
=item --chronology
Check for broken chronology, warn about entries with an old timestamp.
=item -d --skip-dups
Skip duplicated coordinates.
=item B<-e>, --epoch
Use seconds since 1970-01-01 00:00:00 GMT as date format.
item --fix
Comment out entries which is obviously wrong. Use together with --chronology to fix those kind of errors. Does not work with GPX output yet.
=item -h --help
Show this help.
=item --inside
Print only trackpoints inside a rectangle specified by --pos1 and --pos2.
=item --near
Add names of the three closest waypoints to the trackpoint. Unfinished and experimental, needs gpsbabel.
=item -n B<--undefined x>
Use x as undefined value.
=item -o B<--output-format x>
Use output format x:
=over 4
=over 4
=item clean
=item csv
=item gpsml (Default)
This is the format which is meant to be used when storing the track logs. It is line-based XML which makes it easy to edit and grep. Probably not finished yet.
=item gpstrans
=item gpx (Not complete)
=item poscount
Creates a 3D plot where areas with many trackpoints are higher than areas with less track points.
=item ps (Unfinished)
=item svg (Unfinished)
=item xgraph
=item ygraph
=back
=back
Z<>
=item --outside
Print only trackpoints outside a rectangle specified by --pos1 and --pos2.
=item B<--pos1 x> =item B<--pos2 x>
Specifies corners of an area rectangle used by the --inside and --outside options. The x value is in "lat,lon" format (decimal degrees, negative for west or south) .
=item -r B<--require x>
Specify requirements for trackpoints to be written. x is a string with the following flags:
=over 4
=over 4
=item e
=over 4
=item
Print only waypoints which have an elevation.
=back
=back
=over 4
=item p
=over 4
=item
Print only waypoints which have a position.
=item t
=over 4
=item
Print only waypoints which have a timestamp.
=back
=back
=back
Z<>
=item -R --round x=y[,x2=y2[...]]
Round trackpoint element x to y decimals.
Example:
--round lat=4,lon=5,ele=1
=item -s --short-date
Use short date format.
=item -S --save-to-file x
Save the unconverted data to a file with a filename starting with the timestamp of the first trackpoint. The parameter string x is added at the end of the filename. For the time being this option will ignore all other options.
Note: If several files are specified on the command line, all data will be saved into only one file. This behaviour may change in the future.
=item -t --create-breaks
Create breaks in track between points with a difference more than the number of seconds specified by the $PAUSE_LIMIT variable.
=item -u B<--comment-out-dups>
Comment out following data with identical position values, only print first entry.
=item -v --verbose
Verbose output.
=item -w --strip-whitespace
Strip all unnecessary whitespace.
=item -y --double-y-scale
Double Y scale (latitude) to get it right in gnuplot.
=item -h --help
Print a brief help summary.
=item --version
Print version information.
=item --debug
Print debugging messages.
=back
=head1 BUGS
Pretty incomplete in some areas. Some of the source formats are undocumented and thus incomplete. Some functionality is not working properly, for example the Postscript output.
